claim: If a car travels 60 km in 1 hour, it travels 180 km in 3 hours

supporting.text: The speed of the car is constant at 60 km/h, so in 3 hours it will cover 60 km/h * 3 h = 180 km.

attacks.text: The speed of the car is constant at 60 km/h, so in 3 hours it will cover 60 km/h * 3 h = 180 km.
The car's speed may not remain constant due to traffic, road conditions, or mechanical issues.
On highways or under controlled conditions, cars often maintain constant speed for extended periods.
The calculation assumes no stops, but real-world driving includes breaks or refueling.
For theoretical or idealized scenarios, continuous travel without stops is a valid assumption.

supporting.text: Distance traveled is directly proportional to time when speed is constant, hence 3 times the time results in 3 times the distance (180 km).

attacks.text: Distance traveled is directly proportional to time when speed is constant, hence 3 times the time results in 3 times the distance (180 km).

supporting.text: Assuming no acceleration or deceleration, the car maintains a uniform speed, leading to a linear relationship between time and distance (180 km in 3 hours).

With refueling/recharging infrastructure, the car can complete 180 km without speed loss, as demonstrated in endurance tests.
